instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437B: What is 820-3437B? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

Not turning on
No fan spin

All the main rails are present

The only weird stuff is 

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and _SUS which are supposed to be 1.05V and both lines are 1.40V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message: Did you check <SIGNAL>1V05_S0</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C7648</CAPACITOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
Just measured on <CAPACITOR>C7648</CAPACITOR> and its 1.42. 

But the funny thing is that right now it made the RAM BEEPS after pluggin the cord. It didnt happen before!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message: Reflowed the RAM and back to same behavior.. No RAM BEEPS and everything as descripted above!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
You may have a problem with RAM, or CPU.
1.42V at <CAPACITOR>C7648</CAPACITOR> is too high; there could be problems on <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> area.
Check all surrounding components; pay atention to <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR>/12.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message: I already replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and the resistors are <RESISTOR>R7612</RESISTOR> = 40K AND <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR> = 30K on the multimeter measure on another board and gave me the result to be honest. I think they are good... Should I try to reflow the RAM one more time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
1.42V is high too much there!.
Such value can only be caused by faulting components, or corrosion.

Anyway, you can try to adjust the correct voltage playing with mentioned resistors.
Someyime Apple provides a formula for output voltage, based on feedback resistors.
Check page 49 to make an idea; <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> generation, as example.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 80026, member: 682"]
1.42V is high too much there!.
Such value can only be caused by faulting components, or corrosion.

Anyway, you can try to adjust the correct voltage playing with mentioned resistors.
Someyime Apple provides a formula for output voltage, based on feedback resistors.
Check page 49 to make an idea; <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> generation, as example.
[/QUOTE]


Yeah I know its too high

I check all the components around <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> twice.. Still no result

I found <TRANSISTOR>Q1920</TRANSISTOR> missing on the board replaced and still same behavior. Not sure if without would make a difference

Not sure how to try to adjust voltage with the voltage dividers you told me. Would you replace those voltage dividers according to the results on the multimeter being barely different of the schematic?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
Did you see the formula in page 49???

<TRANSISTOR>Q1920</TRANSISTOR> related resistors are good?
Do you get VTT/REF from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>?

BTW, any reason to quote an entire post visible few centimeters above?
Please maintain forum aesthetic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message: Put back <TRANSISTOR>Q1920</TRANSISTOR> and a cap that was missing now I do get back to 1.05v ON <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>... Still no FAN SPIN and CPU gets HOT

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> is OK also
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.73V

Possibly more knocked off components...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
This one was water damaged to be honest with you and went to another store... I am carefully inspecting it and now it doesnt appear as has more components off

I just found its missing <CAPACITOR>C7570</CAPACITOR> / <CAPACITOR>C7541</CAPACITOR>

However I think they would not be the cause to turn on

Now I do have USB Activity.

Still NO FAN SPIN

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
USB activity for sure?
I mean ACTIVITY, not USB power.
If yes, check for external video.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message: Just to let you know! The machine is working 100% now! TKS for everything you are awesome!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message:
Glad to hear it works.
Didn't expect to solve it, being sent out from other service.

Please let feedback with the solution.
This can help other members in the future.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not turning on, no fan spin
threads.message: Actually it was missing a cap around <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and I didnt notice it at first. Then put two more caps <CAPACITOR>C7540</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7570</CAPACITOR> and tried to check USB activity as you told me and the machine was working. I got surprised also
